article.paragraph: Thegaljoen,black bream, orblackfish(Dichistius capensis) is a species of marinefishfound only along the coast of southernAfricafromAngolatoSouth Africa. Galjoen is the national fish of South Africa.
article.heading: Distribution and habitat
article.paragraph: File:Galjoen at Rocky Bay DSC00471.JPGthumbleftGaljoen at Rocky BayThe galjoen is indigenous to the coasts of southernAfricafromAngolaandMadagascartoSouth Africa, and is generally found aroundreefsat shallow depths aroundconvert10mfton, often near the shore.
article.heading: Description
article.paragraph: This species can reachconvert80cminoninfish measurementtotal lengthand a weight ofconvert6.5kglbon. The body is compressed, and the fins are well developed, with prominent spines,10 of them, with between 18 and 23 rays. The anal fin has three spines, and usually 13 or 14 rays, the pelvic fins have 1 spine and 5 rays, and the pectoral fins are typically shorter than the head.The body, fins, and head, with the except of the front of the snout, are covered in scales.cite bookHeemstraPhillip C.Coastal Fishes of Southern Africahttp://books.google.com/books?idJanuary 2004NISC (PTY) LTD978-1-920033-01-9248The lips are thick, with strong curved incisors at the front of the mouth, with smaller teeth behind the front incisors.
article.heading: Ecology
Diet
article.paragraph: The species usually feeds on red and coraline seaweed and red bait, smallmusselsandbarnaclesfound off rocky shores,and appear in particular to be partial to the white mussels residing in the sandy beaches and inlets of the rocky outcrops along the southern coast.
article.heading: Having a home area
article.paragraph: In 2005, Attwood and Cowley extensively studied the movement of the species. tagging some 25,000 galjoen at four sites in reserves in South Africa and concluded that their overall movement remained localised, with some 95% of fish studied seeming to indicate a home area.cite bookCadrinSteven X.KerrLisa A.MarianiStefanoStock Identification Methods: Applications in Fishery Sciencehttp://books.google.com/books?id4 October 2013Academic Press978-0-12-397258-3388
article.heading: Importance to humans
Fishing
article.paragraph: It is important to localcommercial fisheriesand is also popular as agame fish.FishBase speciesDichistiuscapensisApril2013
article.heading: As food
article.paragraph: Due to their abundance in the shores off South Africa, galjoen is common inSouth African cuisine. A notable dish is the fish is sprinkled with pepper and lemon, or with lemon, mayonnaise and melted garlic butter and served with fresh bread and apricot jam.cite bookPaarmanInaWest Coast Cookbookhttp://books.google.com/books?id2003Struik978-1-86872-846-696
article.heading: As the national fish of South Africa
article.paragraph: Galjoen is the national fish of South Africa. The suggestion to make it the national fish came from Margaret Smith, wife of the ichthyologistJ. L. B. Smith, to find a marine equivalent to theSpringbok.cite bookLillDawid VanVan Lill's South African Miscellanyhttp://books.google.com/books?id1 January 2004Zebra978-1-86872-921-051
article.heading: Etymology
article.paragraph: The scientific name ofCoracinus capensisis a reference to its black colour when found in rocky areas,Coracinusmeaning "raven" or "black coloured"; in sandy areas it gives off a silver-bronze colour.
